ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

NON-CITIZEN SPOUSES LIVING IN SINGAPORE
(Policy)


    1. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs what the policy of his Ministry is on applications from non-citizen spouses of Singapore citizens to live in Singapore with their spouses.

    The Minister of State for Law and Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, our immigration laws do not confer upon any foreigner the rights of entry or residence in Singapore. The husband of a Singapore citizen is not entitled to Singapore citizenship or permanent residence by virtue of his marriage to a Singapore citizen. If he desires to settle in Singapore permanently, he will have to obtain permanent residence on his own merits. It is the law and common practice in many countries of the world that a wife should follow her husband, and Singapore is no exception. When a Singapore girl marries a foreigner, she cannot expect the State to grant her husband the right of residence in this country. The husband will have to qualify for residence on his own merits based on the economic contribution he can make to Singapore.

    Our policy on the granting of permanent residence to foreign wives of Singapore citizens is less stringent. However, every case will have to be considered on its own merits. Among the factors to be considered is that we have to ensure that the husband is not only able to support his wife and children but they will not later become a burden to the State if they are granted permanent residence. This is important because we must discourage our citizens who can barely support their families to marry foreign wives, therefore increasing the strain on our public housing, medical and other social services. We must not forget that a person granted permanent residence will be able to form a family nucleus together with one other Singapore citizen for public housing. The grant of permanent residence to each

Column: 1034

applicant will mean that the queue for HDB flats will be longer.

    Singapore has no natural resources and our population density is 3,907 persons per square kilometre which puts us fourth in the world in terms of population density after Monaco, Gibraltar and Hong Kong. We cannot afford to grant permanent residence as liberally as other countries with larger land areas and more resources. In our circumstances, the first responsibility of the Government is to safeguard the rights and interests of the vast majority of Singaporeans.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister has differentiated between non-citizen husbands of Singapore citizens and non-citizen wives of Singapore citizens. If I may take the position of the non-citizen wife. The Minister has said that each case depends on its merits. That begs the question, Mr Speaker, Sir. I want to know what the policy is. The Minister has stated that we have to make sure that the husband is able to maintain the wife. That must equally apply whether or not the wife is a Singapore citizen. The husband is under a duty to maintain the wife under the Women's Charter.

    The Minister has spoken of permanent residence being granted to non-citizen wives. Is he aware that the wives of Singapore citizens have been forcibly ordered to leave this country and kept out because they have contracted marriage with Singapore citizens?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, first, I must ask for clarification from the Member for Anson. Can he clarify his point that wives of Singapore citizens have been forcibly ejected from Singapore because they have contracted marriage? Is he referring to those wives who, before they were married, were work permit holders?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, they were, I think, work permit holders. But the fact remains that they were living in Singapore, and -

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, he has given me the clarification.

Column: 1035



     Mr Speaker: Mr Jeyaretnam, if you are asking a supplementary question, carry on.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, is it the policy of the Ministry to forcibly deport a foreign wife who was previously here on a work permit but who entered into a marriage with a Singapore citizen?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, let me answer the question. In fact, the question has a bearing on the work permit policy which, of course, is administered by the Ministry of Labour. But never let it be said by the Member for Anson that we duck the question on a technicality. Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no question of a forcible or violent overthrow of spouses of Singapore citizens.

    Let us put this question of work permit holders in the correct perspective. Work permit holders are foreigners who have been given work permits. For what reason? To work in Singapore. They are given a work permit in Singapore, precisely because we need them for that limited purpose. They are given a work permit on several conditions which may be imposed by the Commissioner for Employment. These conditions are made known to them. They are aware of the conditions. They accept the conditions and a work permit is then given to them.

    When the Commissioner for Employment has given a work permit, the Immigration Department, which is within the purview of my Ministry, then gives them the necessary visit pass which is coterminous with the duration of the work permit and which is valid for so long as the work permit is valid.

    In situations where any of the conditions is breached, and it may not only be a condition relating to the question of marriage, the Commissioner for Employment may terminate the work permit, again I repeat, for breaching any of the conditions which the work permit holder is fully aware of. When that condition is breached and the work permit is cancelled then, as far as the Immigration Department is concerned, the basis on which the Immigration visit pass was given, that is, the work permit, no longer exists and the person is not per-

Column: 1036

mitted to stay in Singapore. The Member for Anson should know that the legal basis for this is provided for in the Immigration Regulations concerning work permits. Paragraph 9 (A) (3) reads:

    'Where a Work Permit issued to the holder of a Work Permit Pass is cancelled by the Commissioner for Employment, the Work Permit Pass shall be deemed to have been cancelled and the holder of such Pass shall not remain in Singapore thereafter. . . .

I would have thought that this should be familiar to practising lawyers although I can forgive non-lawyers for not being aware of it. It is a simple question of allowing a category of persons to come into Singapore on certain conditions of which they are fully cognizant. They have breached certain conditions and the Work Permit Office cancels the work permit pass and, therefore, the entire basis of their stay in Singapore is negated. The Immigration Department has to follow the law which requires the work permit pass to be deemed cancelled.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Minister please answer my question?

     Mr Speaker: I thought he did answer your question.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, he talks about work permit conditions. My question is this. I want a straight answer to a straight question, Mr Speaker, Sir. Is it the policy of the Ministry to deport the wife of a Singapore citizen albeit when she has broken the condition of her work permit under which she was allowed to live in Singapore? May I have an answer to that question?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, we are having a repetition of what happened yesterday, although I thought the Member for Anson would be a little bit wiser from yesterday's experience. I have given an answer as clearly as possible. The policy is spelt out in the law and the law requires that, when a work permit is cancelled for breach of any condition, the Immigration visit pass is deemed cancelled. Therefore, whether or not that person has any relationship with whosoever in Singapore, that person will be asked to leave.

Column: 1037



     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am raising a point of order. The Member for Anson's line of questioning is such that it would appear that he is championing non-citizens, foreigners. He has forgotten that he has been voted into this House by citizens. But the point of order is this. Will he declare his direct personal pecuniary interest in his line of questioning? In other words, has he got cases of this nature representing non-Singapore citizens regarding application for permanent residence? How many cases has he got, acting as a lawyer outside this House or in the name of his firm "J.B. Jeyaretnam and Company"? Can he declare his interest?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am getting used to all these innuendoes and insinuations which, I am glad to say, are completely ignored by the people outside.

    But be that as it may, may I first put my supplementary question to the Minister who answered the question because he has not answered my question? Does he, first of all, agree that this makes nonsense of the Government's policy about the sacredness of family life and of the husband and wife being allowed to live together?

    Secondly, to answer the Minister's question, I have, as a Member of Parliament, raised about six matters concerning non-citizens who have married Singapore citizens and who have been asked to leave the country.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I take the Member for Anson's answer to mean that he has no pecuniary interest and that he has raised this matter only as an MP but not as a lawyer or in the name of his firm.

    May I refresh his memory that he has done so in his capacity as a lawyer and not as an MP? May I produce a letter from J.B. Jeyaretnam & Company in which it is stated:

    'We act for the abovenamed who is a Malaysian citizen.

    Our client [not a voter] has been residing in Singapore for more than 10 years. On the 17th of May 1981, our client married Mr Latib Bin Ali who is a citizen of Singapore by birth at Johore Bahru by Muslim rites. She now resides with the husband . . .

We would stress that our client's husband is a citizen of Singapore. As such if our client were to leave Singapore it would cause a break-up in the family. . . .'

It is dated 5th February 1982. Can this letter be shown to the Member, Sir? [copy of letter handed in to Mr Speaker.]

     Mr Speaker: Would you like to see this letter, Mr Jeyaretnam?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Yes, Sir.

    [Question No. 2 taken. Later - ]

     Mr Speaker: Is it true that the letter was issued by your firm?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, yes, of course, it is a letter from my firm. It was signed by my assistant. May I continue, Sir? I myself -

     An hon. Member: Not aware?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I do not know what stage this matter has reached, whether there has been any payment or anything on this. Of course, there is this letter. I have raised this matter because of the appeals I have had as the MP for Anson.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson says that the letter was signed by his assistant and he has no personal knowledge of it. Is that so? I take it to mean that.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I do not remember having seen this letter at all in my office.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: And she is not your client? Mr Speaker, Sir, on this subject, I have a letter signed by Mr Jeyaretnam himself with his very big signature. [Copy of letter handed in to Mr Speaker.]

     Mr Speaker: Would you like to see this letter, Mr Jeyaretnam?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Yes, Sir.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, should I answer the supplementary question now?

     Mr Speaker: Yes, please do that.

Column: 1039



     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, in his supplementary question, the Member for Anson asked: does this policy not negate the Government's policy of emphasizing family life in Singapore? On the contrary, the entire immigration policy of Singapore, of which this question touches only a part, is to enhance the quality of life in Singapore, to enhance the quality of family life in Singapore. Therefore, let us always remember, as the immigration policy always stresses, that here we are trying to improve standards of living for all Singaporeans. We are emphasizing the skills of Singaporeans. We are investing a great deal on education. We have taken much effort to cut down the birth rate in Singapore. Is all this to be negated by blindly letting in persons including the illegal immigrants whom the Member for Anson championed yesterday? Are we to let in the indolent, the lazy, the malingerers into Singapore and therefore completely undermine the quality of life for all families of Singaporeans? This is the critical question, Mr Speaker. If Singapore is a land of plenty, we could afford to take a very humanitarian approach in our policy on permanent residence and citizenship. But Singapore is not a land of plenty, so we have to take a strict policy on immigration, a policy that will enhance the quality of life for the vast majority of Singaporeans. Very often, the Government is faced with the problem of making unpleasant and unpopular decisions. When faced with this task, we have to choose that option which is least unpleasant and which is intended to promote the interests of the vast majority of Singaporeans.

     Mr Jeyaretnam rose -

     Mr Speaker: Mr Jeyaretnam, before you say anything more, may I suggest that you refer yourself to the Statutes of Singapore Cap. 49*, section 31, before you commit yourself any more on this particular subject.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: All I want to say is that this second letter that was handed to me was dated 30th May 1981. It is long before I became a Member of Parliament. It is

dated 30th May 1981. Of course, it is my signature. But this signature on the letter dated 5th February 1982 is my assistant's signature. It is about this that I was talking. But the letter dated 30th May 1981, of course it is my signature and I wrote that letter.

BUS SERVICES FOR HOUGANG NEWTOWN


    2. Mr Sia Kah Hui asked the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour, in view of the recent requests from the residents, whether he will indicate what bus services have been planned for Hougang New Town.

     The Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour (Mr Ong Teng Cheong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the development of Hougang New Town is presently centred along Lorong Ah Soo in Neighbourhood I where the first 10 blocks of flats comprising about 1,200 dwelling units have been balloted.

    The SBS will soon provide a feeder service to serve the residents of this neighbourhood. This feeder service, to be designated as Service 321, will link Lorong Ah Soo with Upper Serangoon Road, Upper Paya Lebar Road and Tampines Road. From here, residents can take a total of 14 passing-through trunk services to various parts of the island.

    The SBS has already finalized a comprehensive bus plan for Hougang New Town. Implementation of this can only take place after the bus interchange in the Town Centre is ready in the first quarter of next year. Briefly, a total of seven feeder services will be provided to serve different neighbourhoods. From the bus interchange, a comprehensive network of trunk services will be provided to the Central Business District, neighbouring New Towns and main traffic corridors. The SBS will be most happy to brief the hon. Member for Paya Lebar on further details of its bus plan for Hougang New Town.

DRUG ABUSE AMONG NATIONAL SERVICEMEN
(Measures to eliminate)


    4. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister of Defence what progress has been made on efforts to prevent drug abuse among National Servicemen, and what are the measures taken to eliminate this menace.

     The Minister of State of Defence (Dr Yeo Ning Hong) (for the Minister of Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, in the mid-1970s, drug abuse became a serious problem in Singapore and in the Singapore Armed Forces. At the end of 1976, there were about 2,000 drug abusers among those in the national service. A Special Committee was set up to tackle this problem. Mindef decided to adopt some tough policies and measures which are still enforced today.

    The implementation of these policies and measures have resulted in a rapid and dramatic decline in drug abuse incidents in the military forces.

    631 servicemen were arrested for drug abuse in 1977. The following year, follow-

Column: 1042

ing the measures that I have mentioned earlier, there were only 342 cases; in 1979, 174 cases and in 1980, 168. For 1981, the figure has been further reduced to 132. Thus, in five years from 1977 to 1981, the SAF has succeeded in containing the menace of drug abuse. The number arrested in 1981 was about one-fifth of that for 1977, some five years ago.

    The relapse rate in the SAF, i.e. the percentage of SAF servicemen returning to drug abuse a second time, averages about 15%. This is lower than the national average rate of approximately 45%. This lower relapse rate is due mainly to the strict measures taken in drug abuse detection and to the severe penalties levied on those who were found guilty on the second or subsequent occasion.

    Measures taken against the drug menace in the SAF are a combination of education, detection, severe penalties and rehabilitation.

    Recruits are given talks on the dangers of drug abuse, soon after their enlistment. At that stage, if they admit to having taken drugs before enlistment, they will not be punished. They will be given treatment, rehabilitation and counselling, if necessary.

    Recruits with previous records of drug abuse are identified promptly on enlistment. Their urine is tested every other day for the presence of drugs. This is done throughout their full national service period. It means they have no chance of taking drugs without being detected. In addition, they undergo periodic counselling by trained social workers of the SAF Drug Abuse Rehabilitation Unit.

    Servicemen are also regularly given talks on the ill-effects of drug abuse. They are warned that there will be severe penalties against those who are detected. Publications on drug abuse are distributed throughout the SAF. A book entitled "Curbing Drug Abuse - The SAF Experience" was published in 1981. SAF conducts an annual three month-long anti-drug campaign, during which exhibitions and talks will be organized, and special publications and easily readable pamphlets will be distributed to press home the message of drug abuse and its evils.

Column: 1043



    The SAF carries out urine tests in the units regularly to conduct spot checks which will deter servicemen from drug abuse. Units are selected at random, and their men given no prior warning of the spot checks. Those detected as drug abusers face severe disciplinary penalties. In addition, they undergo rehabilitation and counselling, and once-every-other-day urine test regime.

    The combination of education, certainty of detection, and severe penalties, have brought the drug problem in the SAF very much under control.

It is a serious problem not only in Singapore but also world-wide, where the situation is a lot worse.      Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head U be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead UD-01 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, in the last two months there have been press reports on why the people in Ankara and Taipeh have to suffer from severe air pollution. Whereas Singapore is a small, compact industrialized city-state, no one can disagree that we must have

Column: 1045

stringent control on the emission of toxic substances into the air, otherwise our citizens may have to suffer the same illness as a result of smog and other poisonous fumes in the air. We must not forget, Sir, that more than 70% of our population who live in highrise buildings will be subject to this exposure. Therefore, Sir, the Anti-Pollution Unit has a very important and crucial role in ensuring that the air in Singapore is free from pollutants. I am aware, Sir, that this Unit has been in existence for more than 10 years.

    My question to the Hon. Prime Minister or the Minister responsible is whether he can inform the House of further progress made by this Anti-Pollution Unit; whether this Unit has been able to bring emission of toxic gases under control; whether the level of air pollution is within satisfactory limits, and whether the Unit has any new measures to control air pollution which make Singapore air free for gracious living.

     The Minister for the Environment (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, on behalf of the Prime Minister, let me assure the hon. Member for Punggol that the air in Singapore is generally quite clean.

    The Government is aware of the damage that could be caused by air pollution. Besides Ankara and Taipeh, which are recent cases, there were numerous other cases in the last few years of severe air pollution which affected the health and even lives of many people in other cities.

    When the Anti-Pollution Unit was established more than 10 years ago, it initiated a comprehensive strategy to control air pollution in Singapore. The strategy comprises four main programmes.

    First, the Unit works closely with planning authorities on the siting of industrial estates and residential areas to ensure their compatibility. Within industrial estates, zones have been established for various types of industries according to the propensity to pollute, so that the most pollutive industries will be sited furthest away from residential and commercial developments. All private and public sector development proposals are vetted by the Unit to ensure compatibility according to the zoning concept.

Column: 1046



    Secondly, the Unit compiles an inventory of stationary sources which are likely to cause air pollution.

    Thirdly, the factories that are sources of air pollution are required to comply with emission standards under the Clean Air Act and the Clear Air Standards, using the best practical means of control, i.e., using commonly accepted methods and available equipment. The factories have generally been cooperative and willing to comply with our air pollution standards.

    Lastly, the Unit has 14 permanent air monitoring stations around the island to monitor the level of various air pollutants. The monitoring results act as a feedback as to whether the emission standards have been sufficient to bring air pollution to tolerable limits.

    The main pollutants which are injurious to health and which the Unit monitors are total acidity (made up mostly of sulphur dioxide), ozone, carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxide, smoke and dust.

    Over the last 10 years, the Anti-Pollution Unit has compiled a comprehensive inventory of all major stationary sources which can cause air pollution. The emission of these major sources have been brought under control. The results of these are reflected in the air monitoring results. The average total acidity has fallen. Smoke levels have also shown a marked decrease. Localised dust levels have, however, shown an increase in the last few years. This is mainly because of increased construction activities. Despite the increase, however, the dust levels are still within acceptable limits. Our air quality is good, and is within the long-term standards set by the World Health Organization. As expected, the air is cleaner in rural areas and more polluted in the Jurong industrial area. But even the level of pollution in Jurong is better than accepted standards.
